questions.text: Which of the following structures is tested to check for patency of a Bain's Circuit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patency of a Bain's circuit is evaluated by testing the patency of the inner tube.

Bain Circuit

  • The Bain circuit was introduced by Bain and Spoerel in 1972.
  • It is structurally a coaxial version of the Mapleson D circuit.
  • Fresh gas flows through a 7 mm inner tube within a 22 mm outer expiratory tube.
  • The circuit connects to the anaesthesia machine using a special adapter.

Importance of Patency Check:

  • It is essential to confirm the integrity of the inner fresh gas tube before use.
  • If the inner tube is fractured or disconnected, fresh gas may enter the expiratory limb near the reservoir bag, resulting in excessive dead space.

Pethick's Test (Integrity Test):

  • The test begins by occluding the patient end of the circuit.
  • The reservoir bag is then filled with gas.
  • After opening the patient end, a high oxygen flow is delivered using the oxygen flush valve.
  • If the inner tube is intact, the high gas flow creates a Venturi effect, which reduces pressure in the expiratory limb and causes the reservoir bag to collapse.
  • If the inner tube is disrupted, oxygen enters the expiratory limb and causes the reservoir bag to inflate.

Limitations of Pethick's Test:

  • The test may fail to detect small leaks in the inner tube.
  • Performing the test can itself potentially cause damage to the circuit.
  • If the inner tube is intact but does not reach the patient's end completely, it may result in a significant dead space that cannot be detected by this test.

choices.text: Mapleson D is most effective during controlled ventilation
Mapleson A is most effective during spontaneous ventilation
All Mapleson circuits have reservoir bags
Mapleson circuits have no unidirectional valves

questions.text: All are true about Mapleson circuits except:
questions.solution:
Mapleson circuits, like the Ayre's T-piece type (Mapleson type E), do not have reservoir bags.

In a Mapleson E-type circuit,

  • A length of tubing may be attached to the T-piece to form a reservoir.
  • It does not have a bag.
  • The expiratory port may be enclosed in a chamber from whichexcess gases are evacuated.

Reference: Anesthesia Equipment: Principles and Applications, 2nd Edition, Page Number: 360, 363.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 20 kg has a minute volume of 3 L/min. If the Jackson Rees circuit is used for spontaneous ventilation, how much fresh gas flow should be used for such a patient to prevent rebreathing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fresh gas flow in this case must be 8L/min.

  • The Jackson Rees circuit is a type of Mapleson F system, which lacks unidirectional valves.
  • In Mapleson systems, low fresh gas flow (FGF) can lead to rebreathing of exhaled carbon dioxide.
  • To prevent rebreathing, the recommended FGF should be 2.5 to 3 times the minute ventilation.
  • For this child, the minute ventilation = 3 L/min.
  • Therefore, the required FGF should be between:
    • 2.5 × 3 L/min = 7.5 L/min and
    • 3 × 3 L/min = 9 L/min
  • Thus, to prevent rebreathing in this child using the Jackson Rees circuit, FGF should be set between 7.5 to 9 L/min.

questions.text: Of all the Mapleson circuits lying on the table during a viva, the examiner hands over the circuit that has the fresh gas inlet most distant from the patient connection port. Which circuit should the trainee identify this as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mapleson A differs from the other Mapleson systems in that fresh gas does not enter the system near the patient connection but enters at the other end of the system near the reservoir bag
  • A corrugated tubingconnects the bag to the adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve at the patient end of the system

Mapleson B: The fresh gas enters the system near the patient connection.

Mapleson C: The fresh gas inlet is near the patient end just next to the adjustable-pressure limiting valve (APL).

Mapleson D: The fresh gas floe inlet is near the patient end.

choices.text: Fresh gas flow equal to minute ventilation
Fresh gas flow equal to tidal volume
Fresh gas flow less than minute ventilation
Fresh gas flow less than tidal volume

questions.text: Mapleson A design is the most efficient Mapleson circuit for spontaneous ventilation because:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mapleson A circuits need a fresh gas flow equal to the minute ventilation during spontaneous respiration for efficient functioning.

  • The Mapleson A system is highly efficient for spontaneous breathing when properly designed to preserve dead space gas and vent only alveolar gas.
  • A special valve ensures that exhaled gas isn't released until the reservoir bag is full, allowing effective conservation of useful gases in early exhalation.
  • In this setup, the early part of exhalation (dead space gas) remains within the inspiratory limb and is not wasted.
  • Only the latter part of exhalation (alveolar gas) is expelled once pressure increases enough to open the valve.
  • Because of this gas conservation mechanism, the fresh gas flow required is approximately equal to the patient's minute ventilation-this ensures no rebreathing while minimising gas waste.

questions.text: Which type of Mapleson circuit is shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The system in the image is a modified version of the original Ayre's T-piece, which forms the basis of Mapleson E and F circuits.

Features:

  • A reservoir bag with an adjustable valve has been added to the expiratory limb, which is characteristic of the Jackson-Rees modification.
  • This system connects a two-ended bagto the expiratory limb of the circuit; gas escapes via the 'tail' of the bag.
  • When the valve is left open, the reservoir bag movement helps monitor spontaneous breathing.
  • When the valve is partially closed, the bag can be manually squeezed, allowing controlled ventilation.
  • This is commonly used in pediatric anaesthesia.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not correct for assertion

questions.text:
Identify the correct option regarding the following:
Assertion: Even if there is a leak of other gases in the flowmeter, the patient will not be delivered a hypoxic gas mixture.
Reason: The Oxygen flow meter is upstream of all other gases.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A patient will not be delivered a hypoxic gas mixture even if there is a leak in the flowmeters because the oxygen flow meter is downstream of all other gases.

Importance of Positioning the Oxygen Flowmeter Downstream:

  • To prevent the delivery of a hypoxic gas mixture to the patient.
  • If a leak occurs in or beyond the oxygen flowmeter, it may lead to delivery of a hypoxic gas mixture.
  • To minimise this risk, the oxygen flowmeter is always placed last (downstream) in the sequence, nearest to the vaporiser.

If the oxygen flowmeter is upstream, as in the scenario,

  • Flowmeter sequence: O2 → Middle gas (e.g., air/CO2) → N2O.
  • If there's a leak in the middle tube: 
    • Part of the oxygen escapes through the leak.
    • The patient receives less oxygen and more nitrous oxide (N2O).
    • This can result in a hypoxic gas mixture being delivered.

When the Oxygen Flowmeter is Downstream (correct setup),

  • Flowmeter sequence: N2O → Middle gas (e.g., air/CO2) → O2.
  • If there's a leak in the middle tube:
    • The leak affects the upstream gases (like N2O).
    • Oxygen, being downstream, still reaches the patient.
    • The patient may get more oxygen than intended, causing lighter anaesthesia, but not hypoxia.

choices.text: Have a gas flow rate which depends on viscosity at high turbulent flow
Have a gas flow rate which depends on density at low laminar flow

questions.text: Which of the following facts about flowmeters used in an anaesthesia machine is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The flowmeters are calibrated to be gas-specific.

  • Two types of flowmeters are used in anaesthesia machines:
    • Constant-pressure variable-orifice flowmeters (also called rotameters).
    • Electronic flowmeters.
  • Flowmeters are calibrated for specific gases. (Option A)
  • This is because gas flow behaviour across a constriction changes based on the physical properties of the gas.
  • Therefore, a flowmeter not calibrated for that particular gas can lead to inaccurate flow readings.

Features of a flowmeter:

  • Flow control knobs regulate gas entry into the flowmeter using a needle valve.
  • The tube used is a tapered vertical glass tube (Thorpe tube), not cylindrical. (Option D)
  • The orifice size increases gradually from bottom to top, resulting in a variable diameter.
  • Factors affecting flow rates:
    • At low flow rates (laminar flow), gas flow is influenced by viscosity → governed by Poiseuille's law. (Option C)
    • At high flow rates (turbulent flow), flow is primarily influenced by the gas density. (Option B)

questions.text: Hanger yoke assembly consists of all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hanger yoke assembly consists of Bodok seal, retaining screw, and index pins.

  • The hanger yoke assembly supports the cylinder and connects it to the machine.
  • It has:
    • A body, which is the framework and the supporting structure.
    • The retaining screw, that tightens the cylinder in the yoke. (Option B)
    • The index pins prevent the connection of the wrong cylinder. (Option C)
    • A gas seal(Bodok seal) to prevent a leak between the cylinder and the yoke. (Option A)
    • A filter that removes dirt from the gas.
    • The check valve assembly ensures unidirectional flow.

choices.text: Does not require pressurized gas supply

questions.text: You are using the given device to ventilate a patient. What are the advantages of this bag over the AMBU?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image here shows a breathing bag (reservoir bag) used in anaesthesia circuits that permits tactile feedback, which helps in assessing ventilation and lung compliance, a feature not provided by AMBU bags.

Breathing Bags (Reservoir Bags / Counterlungs) used in anaesthesia machines have the following advantages over AMBU (resuscitation) bags:

  • Manual Ventilation with Feedback:
    • Breathing bags can be squeezed manually, and the resistance felt gives the anesthesiologist tactile feedback on lung compliance and airway pressure.
  • Visual Estimation of Ventilation:
    • The expansion and collapse of the bag allow for visual monitoring of spontaneous breaths and tidal volume.
  • Reservoir Function:
    • They store gas for inspiration, especially important when peak inspiratory flow (20-50 L/min) exceeds fresh gas flow from the anaesthesia machine.

In contrast, AMBU bags:

  • They are self-inflating (Option A) and do not offer the same tactile feedback, as the bag refills automatically and doesn't allow subtle pressure monitoring during manual ventilation.
  • Contain non-rebreathing valves, which complicates the feedback from airway pressure.

questions.text: The viva examiner hands you the following device. Identify the given breathing circuit.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is of a Mapleson D circuit.

  • Features of the Mapleson D circuit:
    • The expiratory valve is located at the end of the expiratory limb (away from the patient).
    • There are no unidirectional valves that direct flow.
    • Effective for controlled ventilation.
    • Spontaneous ventilation is possible but requires high fresh gas flows.
  • The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube.
  • This modification decreases the circuit's bulk and retains heat and humidity better.

Type A Mapleson circuit (Option B): The expiratory valve is near the patient and is efficient for spontaneous breathing.

Type F Mapleson (Option C): The Jackson-Reese circuit has an open/adjustable valve used for pediatric cases.

Type E Mapleson (Option D) has no reservoir bag or expiratory valve.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct
Both assertion and reason are wrong
Assertion is correct but reason is wrong
Assertion is wrong but reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: The Bain breathing system can deliver fresh gas efficiently to the patient with minimal rebreathing.
Reason: In the Bain circuit, the fresh gas flows through an inner tube placed inside the exhalation tubing, allowing gas to be delivered directly to the patient end while expired gas exits near the reservoir bag.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube.

Bain's circuit

  • The Bain circuit is a modified version of the Mapleson D system.
  • It uses a coaxial configuration, where:
    • The fresh gas delivery tube runs inside the larger corrugated expiratory tube.
    • This inner tube extends from the bag mount end to the patient end.
  • The fresh gas exits near the patient, while exhaled gases are vented at the bag end via the pop-off valve.

Potential Malfunction:

  • A critical issue is disconnection of the inner (fresh gas) tube, either:
    • At the entry point near the bag mount.
    • Or at the patient end, from the plastic retainer (spider).
  • Disconnection causes:
    • Increase in apparatus dead space.
    • Decrease in effective alveolar ventilation for the same minute volume.
  • Disconnection at the bag end is more dangerous and may not be visible on inspection.

Tests to Detect Inner Tube Disconnection:

  • Low Flow Occlusion Test
    • Use oxygen at 50 mL/min.
    • Occlude the inner tube (e.g., with a syringe plunger).
    • If the inner tube is intact, the flowmeter bobbin will fall due to back pressure.
  • Venturi Effect Test
    • Fill the reservoir bag with gas.
    • Activate the oxygen flush.
    • A functioning system will create a Venturi effect, causing partial collapse of the bag.
    • Lack of this response may indicate disconnection.

questions.text: Anaesthetic breathing systems can be open or closed. In a closed circuit, which of the following is not used as a carbon dioxide absorber?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While soda lime, Baralyme, and Amsorb are designed to chemically absorb carbon dioxide in closed circuits, silica only serves a structural role and does not absorb CO2.

  • Silica is sometimes added in small amounts to soda lime or other absorbents.
  • Its function is not to absorb CO2, but to improve structural integrity and hardness of the granules.
  • It plays a supportive physical role, not a chemical one.
  • In closed anaesthesia systems, patients re-inhale exhaled gases after carbon dioxide (CO2) is removed.
  • CO2 cannot be vented into the atmosphere as in open systems, so a chemical absorber is necessary.

questions.text: While checking the oxygen supply in the hospital, you measure the pressure of the pipeline gases. Which of the following is the right pipeline pressure for gases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct and safe pipeline pressure for medical gases is 50 psig.

  • Hospitals supply medical gases like oxygen, nitrous oxide, and air to the operating rooms via a central pipeline system.
  • These gases are connected to anesthesia machines using color-coded tubing and Diameter-Index Safety System (DISS) connectors, which prevent incorrect attachments.

Pipeline Pressure Standards

  • The standard pressure at which gases are delivered from the pipeline to the anesthesia machine is approximately 50 psig (pounds per square inch gauge).
  • In countries like the United States, the accepted range for pipeline pressure is generally 50-55 psig, equivalent to 345-380 kPa.
  • Gases like oxygen and nitrous oxide are supplied at a pipeline pressure of 50-55 psig.

Importance of Correct Pressure

  • Maintaining the correct pressure ensures the proper functioning of ventilators, flowmeters, and other anesthesia equipment.
  • Too low or too high a pressure can impair gas delivery or damage the system.
  • Therefore, a daily check of pipeline pressure and gas supply is recommended to minimize risks.

questions.text: While giving anaesthesia to a patient, the oxygen pressure falls below 25 psi. which of the following prevents the delivery of a hypoxic gas mixture in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The delivery of hypoxic gas mixture is prevented by a fail-safe valve.

  • A fail-safe (pressure sensor shut-off) valve is a safety feature in anaesthesia machines.
  • It monitors oxygen supply pressure and regulates the delivery of hypoxic gases like nitrous oxide, carbon dioxide, and helium.
  • When oxygen pressure drops below a preset threshold, this valve reduces or cuts off the flow of these gases to prevent a hypoxic mixture from reaching the patient.

Working Mechanism:

  • In modern anaesthetic machines, the fail-safe valve functions as a variable balance regulator.
  • If oxygen pressure drops, the diaphragm in the valve closes the nitrous oxide pathway proportionally.
  • At 0.5 psig, nitrous oxide flow is fully stopped.
  • For gases like heliox and carbon dioxide, flow is interrupted when oxygen pressure drops below 10 psig.

Diameter index safety system (Option A) is specifically designed to prevent the wrong gas hose from being connected to the machine.

Pin Index Safety System (PISS) (Option B) is a specially designed arrangement of pins and matching holes that acts as a safeguard to prevent the accidental connection of a cylinder containing the wrong gas to the machine.

Pressure relief valve (Option C): Medical gas cylinders are designed with pressure-relief mechanisms to safely release gas if internal pressure becomes dangerously high. This prevents explosions that could occur from overheating or overfilling.

questions.text: Modern vaporisers are
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Modern vaporisers are both agent-specific and temperature-compensated, which ensures safe and stable anaesthetic delivery regardless of environmental or operational variables.

Features of Modern Vaporisers

  • Agent-Specific Design
    • Each vaporiser is built to deliver a specific volatile anaesthetic.
    • This prevents incorrect agent use and ensures accurate concentration delivery.
  • Temperature Compensation
    • Vaporisers contain bimetallic strips (two metals with different thermal expansion properties).
    • These strips adjust the gas flow path based on temperature changes:
      • When the temperature drops, the strip bends to allow more gas into the vaporising chamber.
      • When the temperature rises, the strip bends to restrict gas entry, maintaining a stable output.
    • This mechanism keeps anaesthetic delivery consistent despite environmental temperature changes.
  • Fresh gas flow variations have minimal effect on output concentration due to the fixed bypass ratio.
  • Altitude changes (ambient pressure shifts) do not affect anaesthetic partial pressure, which is what governs clinical effects; thus, no adjustment in dialled concentration is needed. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Tec 6 desflurane vaporiser?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Tec 6 vaporiser is unique in being electrically heated to 39°C, specifically designed for accurate delivery of desflurane.

Tec 6 Desflurane Vaporizer

  • This is specifically designed for desflurane, a potent, inhaled, volatile anaesthetic.

Features:

  • Electrically heated to 39°C
    • The Tec 6 vaporiser heats liquid desflurane to 39°C in a heated chamber (sump).
    • This heating is essential because desflurane has a high vapour pressure and low boiling point; without heating, its vaporisation would be difficult to control.
  • Internal pressure:
    • The internal pressure is around 2 atm. (Option B)
  • Not Pressure-Compensated in the Traditional Sense (Option C)
    • Unlike variable-bypass vaporisers, fresh gas does not enter the sump in Tec 6.
    • Instead, a pressure transducer regulates vapour delivery to match the backpressure from the fresh gas circuit, but this is not the same as true "pressure compensation."
  • Vapour Delivery Mechanism
    • Vapour from the heated sump passes through a variable pressure-regulating valve, which is adjusted based on real-time pressure readings.
    • The user sets the concentration via a dial, and the rotary valve delivers the desired vapour quantity to the fresh gas flow.

questions.text: The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) recommends limiting operating-room concentration of nitrous oxide to ________ ppm:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The NIOSH recommends limiting operating-room concentration of nitrous oxide to 25 ppm.

  • Pollution by anesthetic gases in the operating room can pose health hazards to surgical staff.
  • The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) provides guidelines for safe exposure.
  • The NIOSH provides safety recommendations for exposure to these gases as follows:
  • Nitrous oxide: Limit to 25 ppm (parts per million).
  • Halogenated volatile agents (like isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane):
    • Limit to 2 ppm alone.
    • Limit to 0.5 ppm if used in combination with nitrous oxide.
  • These levels can only be achieved through the use of proper waste-gas scavenging systems, which remove excess anesthetic gases from the breathing circuit.
  • Excess gas is vented via the APL valve and ventilator spill valve, both of which must be connected to the scavenging system to prevent accumulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT found in the low-pressure circuit on an anaesthesia machine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The low-pressure circuit only includes components after the flow control valves, and the oxygen supply failure alarm is not a part of it.

  • The oxygen supply failure alarm, located in the intermediate-pressure system, alerts the clinician with sound and visual cues if oxygen pressure falls below a set minimum level.
  • This alarm is mandatory under ISO standards and, per ASTM guidelines, cannot be silenced until pressure is restored; it's typically triggered by low pipeline pressure or an almost empty oxygen tank.

Low-pressure system

  • The low-pressure circuit of an anaesthesia machine begins after the flow control valves and extends to the fresh gas outlet.
  • It includes critical components such as:
    • Flowmeters or flow sensors: Measure gas after the flow valve. (Option B)
    • Anaesthetic vaporiser: Mix volatile agents with gases. (Option C)
    • Vaporiser manifold: Regulate flow into or out of vaporisers. (Option D)
    • Flow control valves
  • Unlike other parts of the gas delivery system, this section is most susceptible to leaks, making it a key point for safety monitoring.
  • The breathing system, including the circle system, reservoir bag, and ventilator, is considered separately.
  • The high-pressure circuit refers to gas lines before the flow control valves and includes components like gas cylinders and pressure regulators.

questions.text: If you notice that the CO2 absorbent is exhausted during the surgical procedure, which of the following minimal fresh gas flows (L/min) will make the CO2 absorbent unnecessary?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When the CO2 absorber is exhausted, the fresh gas flow is raised to ≥5 L/min to ensure adequate CO2 elimination even without the CO2 absorbers.

  • The circle breathing system allows for rebreathing of exhaled gases, which helps conserve heat and humidity.
  • However, exhaled CO2 must be removed to avoid hypercapnia. This is normally done using a CO2 absorber (e.g., soda lime).
  • At low fresh gas flows (≤1 L/min), a working absorber is necessary to eliminate CO2 effectively.
  • When fresh gas flow exceeds 5 L/min, rebreathing becomes so minimal that the system can function safely without a CO2 absorber.
  • Therefore, if the absorber is exhausted during surgery, increasing the fresh gas flow to ≥5 L/min ensures adequate CO2 elimination, making the absorber unnecessary in that scenario.

choices.text: Has variable control of anaesthetic depth

questions.text: Compared to the Mapleson A system, the circle system
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the Mapleson system, the higher fresh gas flow rate can cause loss of heat, humidity, operating room contamination, and waste of anaesthetic gases. This is overcome in the circle system with the help of additional components, thereby better conserving humidity.

Circle systems

  • The circle breathing system is the most commonly used anesthesia breathing system in developed countries.
  • It is more complex than Mapleson circuits and is specifically designed to minimize rebreathing of exhaled gases.

Components

  • Includes standard parts like:
    • Reservoir bag
    • Breathing tubes
    • Adjustable Pressure-Limiting (APL) valve
    • Fresh gas flow (FGF) inlet
  • Additional components unique to the circle system:
    • Unidirectional inspiratory and expiratory valves
    • Carbon dioxide (CO2) absorber
    • Y-piece connector

Functioning of the Circuit

  • The fresh gas inlet delivers gases to the inspiratory limb, which is equipped with a one-way valve.
  • Gas travels through the Y-piece to the patient's airway.
  • Upon exhalation, gas flows from the patient through the Y-piece to the expiratory limb, passing another unidirectional valve.
  • Exhaled gases enter a section with the reservoir bag and APL valve, and then pass into the CO2 absorber before re-entering the inspiratory limb.

Rebreathing and Heat Conservation

  • Patients re-inhale part of the exhaled gas after CO2 removal, allowing for:
    • Conservation of heat and humidity
    • Reuse of volatile anesthetics
  • This enhances patient comfort and reduces anesthetic gas consumption.

Role of the CO2 Absorber

  • The CO2 absorber eliminates carbon dioxide from exhaled gas via a chemical reaction.
  • CO2 reacts with water to form carbonic acid, which is neutralized by hydroxide salts (strong bases) in the absorber.
  • This neutralization produces calcium carbonate, heat, and moisture.
  • Soda lime is a common absorbent and contains:
    • Calcium hydroxide
    • Sodium hydroxide
    • Potassium hydroxide
    • Water

Absorbent Granules and Color Indicator

  • Absorbent materials are in the form of granules (typically 4-8 mesh in size).
  • These granules contain a pH-sensitive dye (commonly ethyl violet) that changes color when the absorber becomes ineffective.
  • A color change in 50-70% of granules signals the need for canister replacement to prevent CO2 retention and rebreathing.

choices.text: It contains a nonrebreathing valve, same as the circle system
It is capable of delivery of nearly a 100% O2 concentration
Patient valve has low resistance to both inspiration and expiration

questions.text: While resuscitating a patient, the following device is used for ventilation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The AMBU bag uses a nonrebreathing valve, while the circle system uses unidirectional valves that allow controlled rebreathing. Unlike the circle system, the AMBU does not direct gas through a CO2 absorber, and all exhaled gas is released into the atmosphere.

AMBU BAGS

  • An AMBU bag, also known as a bag-mask resuscitator, is a handheld device used for emergency ventilation.
  • It is widely favoured for its simplicity, portability, and ability to deliver nearly 100% oxygen (Option B) when connected to a high-flow source.
  • It is frequently used during resuscitation and intubation to maintain oxygenation, especially in critically ill patients and enables both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

Key Components and Mechanism:

  • Nonrebreathing Valve:
    • Allows inhaled gases to reach the patient while venting exhaled gases to the environment, thereby preventing rebreathing.
    • This is a key difference from systems like the circle system that permit rebreathing.
  • Self-refilling Ventilation Bag:
    • The compressible bag refills automatically via a fresh gas inlet.
    • During compression, an intake valve closes, enabling positive-pressure ventilation. (Option C)
  • Reservoir Valve Assembly:
    • Contains two unidirectional valves:
      • Inlet valve: Allows ambient air entry if fresh gas flow is inadequate.
      • Outlet valve: Opens to release excess oxygen if the flow is too high.

choices.text: It has been decreased to half the original volume

questions.text: You are preparing to set up for anesthesia in an off-floor location in the interventional radiology suite. The radiography equipment is consuming the limited space that is available in the suite, and therefore, the decision is made to double the extension tube length from the ventilator to the patient table. What is the impact on the dead-space ventilation that would have occurred secondary to doubling the extension tubing length?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The length of the extension tube does not affect the dead space as the area beyond the Y-piece in a circle system does not contribute to it.

  • Dead space refers to the portion of each breath that does not participate in gas exchange in the alveoli.
  • In a circle breathing system, due to the presence of unidirectional valves, the only part of the circuit contributing to dead space is the area beyond the Y-piece, where inspiratory and expiratory gases mix.
  • Therefore, anything proximal to the Y-piece, including added tubing between the ventilator and the patient, does not increase dead space.

Effect of Tubing Length on Dead Space

  • Doubling the extension tubing length in a circle system does not alter the dead space, because it is located before the point of gas mixing (Y-piece).
  • This is unlike Mapleson circuits, where tubing length does contribute to dead space.
  • However, increasing the length does increase circuit compliance, which may lead to more tidal volume being lost during positive-pressure ventilation-but that affects ventilation mechanics, not dead space volume.

questions.text: Malfunction of which of the following valves within a circle system may cause rebreathing of carbon dioxide and could potentially result in hypercapnia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The malfunction of the unidirectional valves in a circle system may cause hypercapnia as a result of rebreathed exhaled CO2.

Causes and Consequences of Equipment Malfunction in Ventilation

  • Ventilator misconnections can result in dangerous complications like hypoxia (low oxygen) or hypercapnia (elevated CO2 levels).
  • A faulty unidirectional valve in the breathing circuit can increase dead space and cause the patient to rebreathe exhaled CO2. (Option C)
  • If soda lime is exhausted, especially with low fresh gas flow, it fails to absorb CO2 effectively, again leading to rebreathing.
  • Capnography can help detect CO2 rebreathing by showing its presence during the inspiratory phase.
  • In case of suspected equipment failure, the anesthesia machine should be bypassed, and the patient should be ventilated manually using a resuscitation (AMBU) bag until the issue is resolved.

Malfunction in either of the unidirectional valves within a circle system could result in the accumulation and eventual CO2 rebreathing that may result in hypercapnia.

questions.text: Degradation of sevoflurane by soda lime results in the production of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane degradation by soda lime leads to the formation of Compound A, making it the correct choice.

  • Sevoflurane was used in Japan from the 1970s but received FDA approval in the U.S. only in 1995.
  • During its early development, a byproduct called Compound A was identified.
  • Compound A (fluoromethyl-2,2-difluoro-1-(trifluoromethyl) vinyl ether) is formed when sevoflurane reacts with alkalis like soda lime.
  • This occurs through the elimination of hydrogen fluoride from the isopropyl group in sevoflurane.
  • Toxicity:
    • Compound A is nephrotoxic and potentially lethal at high levels.
  • Factors increasing Compound A production:
    • Low fresh gas flows
    • High inspired sevoflurane concentrations
    • Dehydrated absorbents
    • Elevated absorbent temperature
  • Safe Usage Guidelines
    • Flows 1-2 L/min are considered safe for <2 MAC-hours.
    • Flows <2 L/min should not exceed 2 MAC-hours.
    • Flows <1 L/min are not recommended at all with sevoflurane.

questions.text: In a CO2-absorbent canister, the greatest amount of carbon monoxide is produced by which of the following volatile agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carbon Monoxide Formation in Anaesthesia Breathing Systems

Role of Desiccated Absorbents:

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) production is strongly associated with dried-out (desiccated) carbon dioxide absorbents.
  • Desiccation usually occurs due to prolonged high oxygen flow over the absorbent, especially over weekends.

Volatile Agents Involved:

  • When exposed to dry absorbents, modern anaesthetics like desflurane, enflurane, and isoflurane can degrade into CO.
  • These agents contain the -O-CHF2 moiety, key to CO production during breakdown.
  • Desflurane produces the most carbon monoxide, followed by enflurane and then isoflurane (Option C).
  • Sevoflurane and halothane do not significantly produce CO, as they lack the -O-CHF2 group. (Option A & B)

Mechanism and Risk Factors:

  • CO production is enhanced when absorbents are dry, the temperature is high, and anaesthetic concentrations are increased.

Absorbent Type Matters:

  • Barium hydroxide lime leads to more carbon monoxide production compared to soda lime.
  • Nonetheless, both absorbents produce more CO under dry and high-temperature conditions.
